case_name: Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. their workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 459 and 460 of 1957 were filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated 30th November 1956 of the Industrial Tribunal Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 459 and 460 of 1957. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 30th November, 1956, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference 1. T. Nos. 10 and 13 of 1956.

facts.text: Industrial dispute in Reference I.T. No. 10 of 1956 involved demand for bonus equivalent to seven months basic wages with dearness allowance by workmen of Associated Cement Companies Ltd., Cement Marketing Company of India Ltd., and Concrete Association of India, all at Bombay offices.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals arise out of a demand for bonus made against the appellants by their workmen for the year 1953-54. The Associated Cement Companies Ltd., Bombay, the Cement Marketing Company of India Ltd., Bombay and the Concrete Association of India, Bombay, were faced with a demand of their workmen employed in their offices at Bombay for bonus equivalent to seven months basic wages with dearness allowance.

facts.text: Industrial dispute in Reference I.T. No. 13 of 1956 involved demand for bonus equivalent to 50% of total earnings or six months total earnings by workmen of Associated Cement Companies Ltd., Dwarka Cement Works.

anchor.surface_text: The industrial dispute arising out of this demand was referred by the Government of Bombay for adjudication before the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act and it was numbered I. No. 10 of 1956. The Associated Cement Companies Ltd., Dwarka Cement Works, Dwarka, was similarly faced with a demand of its workmen for bonus equivalent to 50 of total earnings or six months total earnings.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal Bombay delivered award on November 30 1956 directing companies to pay bonus equivalent to 1/3 of basic wages or pay less bonus already paid for 1953-54 to workmen drawing up to Rs. 500 per month.

anchor.surface_text: By its award delivered on November 30, 1956, the tribunal directed the companypanies to pay their workmen drawing a basic pay or wages up to Rs. 500 per month bonus equivalent to 1/3 of their basic wages or pay  less bonus already paid for the year 1953-54  subject to the companyditions specified in the award.

facts.text: Associated Cement Companies Ltd. (A.C.C.) paid bonus equivalent to three months basic wages for 1953-54 to its employees, and Cement Marketing Company of India Ltd. (C.M.I.) did the same to its workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The A. C. C. had already paid to its employees bonus equivalent to three months basic wages for the year 1953-54 and so had the C. M. I. to its workmen. It appears that the C. M. I., including the C. A. I., undertakes to pay to its employees the same amount of bonus as has been paid or awarded to the employees of the A. C. C.

facts.text: A.C.C. is the biggest cement manufacturing company in India, owning 15 cement factories in India and 2 in Pakistan, despatching 55.46% of total cement from Indian factories in 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the A. C. C. is the biggest amongst the companypanies in India which manufacture cement. It owns 15 cement factories at different places in India and 2 in Pakistan. Out of the total quantity of cement despatched by all the cement factories in India in 1953-54 the A. C. C. despatched 55.46 .

facts.text: A.C.C. came into existence in 1936 by merger of four groups: E. Dinshaw, Tatas, Killick Nixon and Khatau, involving 11 companies.

anchor.surface_text: The A. C. C. came into existence in 1936 as a result of the merger of four important groups of companypanies engaged in the manufacture of cement. These were E. Dinshaw, Tatas, Killick Nixon and Khatau, groups. It appears that 11 companypanies in all merged with the A. C. C.

facts.text: Respondents (workmen) alleged A.C.C. held monopoly position and could pay claimed bonus.

anchor.surface_text: Before the tribunal the case for the respondents was that the appellant held a position of monopoly in the cement industry and was easily in a position to pay the bonus claimed by them.

facts.text: Respondents alleged appellant inflated capital invested by merging companies in 1936, set up new factories from profits without fresh capital, capitalized premium-on-shares and transferred reserves for 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: Their allegation was that the appellant had inflated the capital invested by the merging companypanies while taking them over in 1936 it had set up new factories out of the profits earned by it without raising fresh capital and thereby had used profits for the purpose of expansion. In the year 195354 the appellant had capitalised the full amount standing to the credit of the premium-on-shares account and had transferred a part of the reserves for taxation to the capital account thus increasing the aggregate capital.

facts.text: Tribunal held appellant did not inflate capital invested by merging companies in 1936.

anchor.surface_text: It has held that the appellant had number inflated the capital invested by the merging companypanies while taking them over in 1936.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed 6% interest on entire paid-up capital of Rs. 1267.59 lakhs and 4% on working capital.

anchor.surface_text: It has allowed 6 interest on the entire paid-up capital of Rs. 1267.59 lakhs, and 4 interest on the working capital.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected appellant's claim for rehabilitation, replacement and modernisation based on Ex. C-2 as exaggerated.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal examined the evidence of Mr. Tongaonkar as well as Ex. C-2 and other documents produced by him, and came to the companyclusion that Ex. C-2 presents an incorrect and exaggerated picture of the A.C.C.s requirements of rehabilitation and replacement and so it cannot be relied upon.

facts.text: Appellant claimed provision for rehabilitation of Rs. 284.48 lakhs under Full Bench formula.

anchor.surface_text: The result is the sum of Rs. 284.48 lakhs, and that is claimed by the appellant as the provision for rehabilitation under the formula.

facts.text: Agreement came into operation from August 1, 1953, making C.M.I. financial transactions part of A.C.C. accounts.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the agreement which came into operation from August 1, 1953, all financial transactions of the C. M. 1. in relation to sales number find a place in the accounts of the A. C. C. Similarly all of its fixed assets have been taken over and appear in the balance-sheets of the C. C.

facts.text: Cement Marketing Company of India Ltd. is 100% subsidiary of A.C.C., Concrete Association of India is department of C.M.I., common staff in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The Cement Marketing Company of India Ltd.,  hereafter -called the C. M. I.  has been separately registered under the Indian Companies Act as a Joint Stock Company but it is a hundred per cent. subsidiary of the A. C. C. The C. M. I. are the Sales Managers of the A. C. C. while the Concrete Association of India  hereafter called the C. A. I.  is merely a department of the C. M. 1. All the three companycerns have a companymon staff in Bombay.

facts.text: In previous adjudication Ref. I.T. No. 115 of 1953 for 1951-52, appellant claimed Rs. 192-193 lakhs for rehabilitation.

anchor.surface_text: It thought that for rehabilitation the appellant had claimed numbermore than Rs. 192 or 193 lakhs in the previous adjudication proceedings where the dispute for bonus had reference to the year 1951-

facts.text: Appellant submitted programme to Tariff Commission estimating Rs. 18.36 crores over 10 years from 1-8-1952 to 31-7-1962 for rehabilitation etc., approx Rs. 184 lakhs per year.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in the said programme the appellant had made out a case for the estimated expenditure of Rs. 18.36 crores to be spread over a period of ten years from 1-8-1952 to 31-7-1962 and that works out approximately at the figure of Rs. 184 lakhs per year.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed Rs. 165-170 lakhs as annual provision for rehabilitation, replacement and modernisation based on actual spend of Rs. 339.76 lakhs in 1952-53 and 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately the tribunal came to the companyclusion that in the circumstances of the case it would be fair to allow the appellant about Rs. 165 to 170 lakhs as annual provision for the said items. In support of this companyclusion the tribunal has relied on the fact that for the two years 1952-53 and 1953-54 the appellant had spent about Rs. 339.76 lakhs for the purpose of rehabilitation, replacement land modernisation and that works at the average of Rs. 170 lakhs per year.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds tribunal erred in estopping appellant from claiming more than Rs. 192 lakhs for rehabilitation based on past claims.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the tribunal was in error in companying to the companyclusion that by reason of its previous companyduct the appellant companyld number be allowed to place its claim for rehabilitation at a figure higher than Rs. 192 lakhs in the relevant year.

facts.text: Ex. C-2 prepared by Mr. Tongaonkar shows total annual rehabilitation requirement of Rs. 3,29,61,752 based on blocks classified by purchase years.

anchor.surface_text: The total annual requirement of the appellant in respect of rehabilitation is shown as of the order of Rs. 3,29,61,752.

facts.text: A.C.C. had plant reinstatement reserve of Rs. 235 lakhs and general reserve of Rs. 76 lakhs at beginning of 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has then taken into account the fact that the appellant had a plant reinstatement reserve of Rs. 235 lakhs and a general reserve of Rs. 76 lakhs in the beginning of the year 1953-54.

facts.text: Full Bench formula evolved by Labour Appellate Tribunal in 1950 in Mill Owners Association case.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with the merits of the points raised in these appeals it would be companyvenient to refer to the genesis and the terms of the formula which has been evolved by the Full Bench of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in the case of The Mill Owners Association, Bombay v. The Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay  1  in 1950.

facts.text: Supreme Court decides not to revise Full Bench formula for bonus calculation.

anchor.surface_text: That is why we think that labours claim for bonus should be decided by tribunals on the basis of the formula without attempting to revise it.

facts.text: Depreciation under formula is notional normal depreciation as per Surat Electricity case.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that the depreciation which has to be deducted from the gross profits should be the numberional numbermal depreciation as explained in the case of Surat Electric Co., Ltd.  1 .

facts.text: Income-tax calculation under formula takes into account concessions for initial and additional depreciation under Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, bold that in calculating the amount of tax payable for the bonus year the tribunals should number take into account the companycessions given by the Income-tax Act to the employers under the two more depreciations allowed under s. 10 2  vi  of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The emoluments of the workers were inadequate and so they were entitled to the bonus claimed by them in order to fill up the gap between the actual wage paid to them and the living wage due to them.

holdings.text: The tribunal was in error in concluding that by reason of its previous conduct the appellant could not be allowed to place its claim for rehabilitation at a figure higher than Rs. 192 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the tribunal was in error in coming to the conclusion that by reason of its previous conduct the appellant could not be allowed to place its claim for rehabilitation at a figure higher than Rs. 192 lakhs in the relevant year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Previous statements to Tariff Commission and prior adjudication not exhaustive claims under formula; hypothetical assessments do not create estoppel.

holdings.text: Strict legalistic principles like estoppel should generally not be applied in industrial adjudication when assessing rehabilitation claims.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it would be pertinent to remember that in dealing with the employers claim for rehabilitation the tribunal is called upon to assess respective values of the relevant factors on hypothetical and empirical considerations, and so it may generally not be useful or wise to take recourse to strict legalistic principles like estoppel in deciding this question and indeed all material questions in industrial adjudications.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Industrial adjudication involves hypothetical empirical assessments; strict rules inappropriate.

holdings.text: Labour's claim for bonus should be decided by tribunals on the basis of the Full Bench formula without attempting to revise it.

anchor.surface_text: That is why we think that labours claim for bonus should be decided by tribunals on the basis of the formula without attempting to revise it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Formula has worked satisfactorily; revision requires comprehensive consideration by legislature or commission; apply elastically based on evidence.

holdings.text: The depreciation to be deducted from gross profits is the notional normal depreciation as explained in Surat Electric Co. case.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that the depreciation which has to be deducted from the gross profits should be the notional normal depreciation as explained in the case of Surat Electric Co., Ltd.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Full Bench and Surat Electricity; initial/additional are abnormal, defeat formula's object.

holdings.text: In calculating income-tax payable for bonus year, tribunals should take into account concessions for initial and additional depreciation under s.10(2)(vi) Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, hold that in calculating the amount of tax payable for the bonus year the tribunals should take into account the concessions given by the Income-tax Act to the employers under the two more depreciations allowed under s. 10(2)(vi) of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notional tax must reflect statutory concessions; bonus year self-contained; consistent with Sree Meenakshi Mills.

holdings.text: Bonus year treated as self-sufficient unit; no inclusion of excess profits tax refunds or adjustment of prior losses/depreciation under s.24 Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: the bonus year is taken as a unit self-sufficient by itself ... the allowance for adjustment which the employer claims cannot be taken into account in determining the amount of income-tax payable on the profits of the bonus year under the formula.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Formula basis treats year independently; follows Labour Appellate Tribunal decisions.

holdings.text: Rates of return on paid-up capital and working capital are not fixed at 6% and 2-4%; to be fixed according to circumstances of each case.

anchor.surface_text: We think that this is a correct approach and that it is necessary to fix the rates of interest on the two items of paid-up capital and working capital according to the circumstances of each case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunals modify rates per facts; follows prior decisions like Assam Co., Ruston.

holdings.text: Provision for rehabilitation, replacement and modernisation calculated by estimating probable replacement cost of blocks (plant/machinery and buildings) divided by estimated life.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it would be pertinent to remember that in dealing with the employers claim for rehabilitation the tribunal is called upon to assess respective values of the relevant factors on hypothetical and empirical considerations, and so it may generally not be useful or wise to take recourse to strict legalistic principles like estoppel in deciding this question and indeed all material questions in industrial adjudications.

In this connection it would be pertinent to remember that in dealing with the employers claim for rehabilitation the tribunal is called upon to assess respective values of the relevant factors on hypothetical and empirical considerations, and so it may generally not be useful or wise to take recourse to strict legalistic principles like estoppel in deciding this question and indeed all material questions in industrial adjudications.
